repo.name: neovim

body:
This commit also implements more generic trimming, acting on all
whitespace (charwise) rather than just empty lines.

It will unblock
https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/pull/3442 and allow
for properly concealing markdown bullet markers regardless of indent
width, e.g.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        `metadata[capture_id].range`. Trims blank lines from the end of the node
        by default (for backwards compatibility). Trims all whitespace from both
        sides of the node if the optional parameter "1" is given.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -385,14 +385,19 @@ The following directives are built in:
             (#gsub! @_node ".*%.(.*)" "%1")
 <
     `trim!`                                          *treesitter-directive-trim!*
-        Trim blank lines from the end of the node. This will set a new
-        `metadata[capture_id].range`.
+        Trim whitespace from the node. This will set a new
+        `metadata[capture_id].range`. The directive takes an optional
+        parameter following the capture group to determine whether to trim all
+        whitespace from both sides of the node (when set to `1`), or to only
+        trim blank lines from the end of the node (this is the default, for
+        backwards compatibility).

comment_regular_data.body: Won't that be backward-incompatible? Maybe we can make the trim configurable with parameters?
sure I can do that. Also is there a way to ignore linter errors for lines containing only whitespace? with a comment or something

>  with a comment or something

Yes but I don't remember exactly how (with stylua). For luacheck, you just `push` the error number (and `pop` afterwards).

Is the backwards compatibility option a dealbreaker here? Seems like there aren't [too many](https://github.com/search?q=lang%3Ascheme+%23trim%21&type=code&p=2) instances of this (at least on github) and having two different trim functions / options might make maintenance more difficult

For anything that requires proper charwise trimming, e.g. it would fix https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/pull/3442 and would allow for properly concealing markdown bullet markers regardless of indent width, e.g.

> Is the backwards compatibility option a dealbreaker here? 

Kinda, yes -- it's used extensively in fold queries, and these have to work across different Neovim versions. But adding (a) parameter(s) that control additional trimming and defaulting to the old behavior if these are omitted would be fine.

> For anything that requires proper charwise trimming, e.g. it would fix [nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#3442](https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/pull/3442) and would allow for properly concealing markdown bullet markers regardless of indent width, e.g.

This kind of information needs to be included in the OP, and probably in the commit message too.
Should I add a `TODO` for myself to remove the old trimming functionality after a future release?

> Should I add a `TODO` for myself to remove the old trimming functionality after a future release?

Not sure that's necessary -- isn't the old functionality a strict subset of the new functionality (`#trim! 0 0 0 1`)?

~Not strictly speaking (`#trim! 0 0 0 1` would trim all trailing *blank* lines (may contain whitespace) and the old `#trim!` just trimmed *empty* lines (must == `""`)). But I think the difference would be so subtle that it's probably still fine not to add a TODO~

Edit: based on your above comment I am just going to make the old trim a true subset of this (so it does trim blank lines, not just empty ones) and I'm sure like you say it will just be an improvement

Alright comments have mostly been addressed, I still need to document the new directive parameters, but now the backwards compatibility test fails due to an index out of bound error ~and I have no clue why~
